metadata.creator: Anthony Mark LaMort
metadata.description:
Artful Update - Musical Sketch - Ode to a Little Yellow Bug

He ... or she ... But please, not it... was one of my stowaways the other day. A particularly wet, blustery day and I had all kinds of creatures hitching a ride.

I took care of them the best I could, moving them to the few dry places in the cockpit - placing them on dry cloths so the capillary action would dry their tiny wings (this works very well, by the way). So Little Yellow Bug first landed on my tiller hand and seemed quite happy there. Strangely active although "standing" in one place - his ... or her antennae waved about curiously. A charming insect. I wish I had gotten a picture but I was a bit busy at the time. I tried to move her... or him... into one of the dry places for the duration but s/he would have it. So s/he flew to the cockpit sole grating (just strips of teak really) and that seemed as good a place as any.

I didn't think much more of LYB for awhile - I had a boat to try to keep upright. Later, when things were calm and I was straightening up all the things that had been disheveled. I found LYB - crushed by one of my gas cans. They're tied down but it must have shifted somewhat and crushed LYB where she... or he... was hiding.

Now you may laugh and say that I am a sentimental fool or overly emotional and I'm sure you'd be right - but I felt such a sense of loss. Even guilt. I should have tied those gas cans more tightly. As I held the tiny crushed insect in my hand wishing more powerfully than you can imagine, that it was still alive, the breeze carried him... or her... Away.

Get ahold of yourself man - it was just a bug. How true but...

No better words on the topic than those of William Blake:

***

Little Fly, 
Thy summer's play 
My thoughtless hand 
Has brushed away.

Am not I 
A fly like thee? 
Or art not thou 
A man like me?

For I dance 
And drink, and sing, 
Till some blind hand 
Shall brush my wing.

If thought is life 
And strength and breath 
And the want 
Of thought is death;

Then am I 
A happy fly, 
If I live, 
Or if I die.

***

But there is also a larger lesson: it wasn't really my fault. Or the bug's fault. It just happened. A large thing crushed a small being simply in virtue of it being there. The works of man have become so very large. So very mighty. H
They threaten to crush - being by being Mother Earth whom we claim to love. Tread lightly for we are all sharing the earth and sea and sky and in a way, we are after all, all precious little yellow bugs...

- - - - - -

The piece is reflective first of the curiosity,activity, and perhaps inherent comedy of such a creature. There's a touch of the "otherworldly" for insects can be just that, and there are elements of the sacred and human - for I believe all life is sacred and we are connected intimately with every living entity.

The place of pathos and sorrow is obvious.

I end the piece with a kind of questioning hopefulness: (from my own theological take) in the Resurrection will I see all the creatures I have tried to nurse back to health and moreover, all the ones I have killed inadvertently or otherwise? Will they forgive me and will I forgive whatever kills me? But then maybe that is what "heaven" is - the place where all is forgiven.


Composed by 
Rev. Anthony Mark LaMort
Aboard s/v Artful Dodger
7. June, 2016


(Better video, same audio here at archive.c and also at

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dIHn3Df2V4c)
